kinematics.text: Why do we need the concept of speed? Where does it come from?
kinematics.hint: Think about what question speed answers. How else could you describe an object's motion?

kinematics.text: What's the difference between speed and velocity? Why does direction matter?
kinematics.hint: Consider two cars traveling at 60 mph - one north, one south. Are they moving the same way?

kinematics.text: Why is acceleration the 'rate of change of velocity'? What does this mean intuitively?
kinematics.hint: Think about what changes when you press the gas pedal or brake pedal in a car.

kinematics.text: If I drop two objects simultaneously from the same height, why do they hit the ground at the same time regardless of mass (ignoring air resistance)?
kinematics.hint: Consider Newton's second law and how gravity affects different masses.

forces-momentum.text: What does it really mean that 'an object in motion stays in motion'? Why doesn't everything around us just keep moving forever?
forces-momentum.hint: Consider what forces act on everyday objects like a rolling ball or a moving car.

forces-momentum.text: If F=ma, why does a heavy box feel harder to push than a light box?
forces-momentum.hint: To achieve the same acceleration, what must change in the equation?

forces-momentum.text: When you push on a wall, the wall pushes back with equal force (Newton's 3rd law). So why don't you move?
forces-momentum.hint: Consider what other forces are acting on you, like friction with the ground.

forces-momentum.text: Why can a rocket work in space where there's nothing to 'push against'?
forces-momentum.hint: Think about action-reaction pairs. What is the rocket pushing?

work-energy-power.text: What IS energy? Why is it useful to have this concept?
work-energy-power.hint: Think about what's conserved when a ball bounces, when you climb stairs, or when a car brakes.

work-energy-power.text: Why do we say energy is 'conserved' when a bouncing ball clearly loses energy and stops bouncing?
work-energy-power.hint: Where does the energy go? Is it destroyed or transformed?

work-energy-power.text: How can potential energy exist 'in' an object? Is it really stored there?
work-energy-power.hint: Consider the relationship between the object and Earth. Could potential energy exist for a single object alone in space?

rigid-body-mechanics.text: Why is it harder to open a door by pushing near the hinges compared to the handle?
rigid-body-mechanics.hint: Think about the concept of torque and the lever arm distance.

rigid-body-mechanics.text: What does moment of inertia represent for rotation compared to mass for linear motion?
rigid-body-mechanics.hint: Consider how distribution of mass affects resistance to rotational change.

rigid-body-mechanics.text: Why does a spinning ice skater spin faster when they pull their arms in?
rigid-body-mechanics.hint: Think about conservation of angular momentum and how changing the radius affects velocity.

galilean-relativity.text: If you drop a ball inside a moving train, where does it land relative to you? What about relative to someone outside?
galilean-relativity.hint: Think about the initial horizontal velocity of the ball.

galilean-relativity.text: Why do the laws of physics appear the same in all inertial frames of reference?
galilean-relativity.hint: Consider if you could perform an experiment to determine if you are moving at a constant velocity without looking outside.

galilean-relativity.text: What happens to time and length as you approach the speed of light in Special Relativity?
galilean-relativity.hint: Think about time dilation and length contraction effects.

thermal-energy-transfers.text: Why does metal feel colder than wood at the same room temperature?
thermal-energy-transfers.hint: Think about thermal conductivity and how fast heat leaves your hand.

thermal-energy-transfers.text: How does a thermos keep hot coffee hot and cold water cold?
thermal-energy-transfers.hint: Consider the three modes of heat transfer: conduction, convection, and radiation.

thermal-energy-transfers.text: Why does sweating cool you down?
thermal-energy-transfers.hint: Think about the energy required for phase change from liquid to gas.

greenhouse-effect.text: Why doesn't the Earth just keep getting hotter if the Sun is constantly heating it?
greenhouse-effect.hint: Think about energy balance: energy in versus energy out.

greenhouse-effect.text: How do greenhouse gases actually 'trap' heat? Do they stop it from leaving?
greenhouse-effect.hint: Consider absorption and re-emission of infrared radiation.

greenhouse-effect.text: Is the greenhouse effect always bad? What would Earth be like without it?
greenhouse-effect.hint: Compare Earth's average temperature to the Moon's.

gas-laws.text: Why does a balloon shrink when you put it in the freezer?
gas-laws.hint: Think about the motion of gas molecules and how temperature affects their speed.

gas-laws.text: Why does the pressure in a tire increase after driving on a hot day?
gas-laws.hint: Consider the relationship between temperature and pressure at constant volume.

gas-laws.text: What defines an 'ideal' gas? When do real gases fail to behave ideally?
gas-laws.hint: Think about assumptions regarding particle volume and intermolecular forces.

thermodynamics.text: Can you build an engine that is 100% efficient? Why or why not?
thermodynamics.hint: Consider the Second Law of Thermodynamics and entropy.

thermodynamics.text: What does entropy really measure? Is it just disorder?
thermodynamics.hint: Think about the number of possible microstates for a given macrostate.

thermodynamics.text: Why does heat naturally flow from hot to cold?
thermodynamics.hint: Think about probability and the statistical nature of particle collisions.

current-circuits.text: Does a battery run out of electrons?
current-circuits.hint: Think about what a battery actually provides to the circuit (energy, not charge).

current-circuits.text: Why do lights in a house turn on instantly if electrons move very slowly (drift velocity)?
current-circuits.hint: Think about a line of marbles or water in a pipe. When you push one end, how fast does the other end move?

current-circuits.text: Why is it safer to touch a 10,000V Van de Graaff generator than a 120V wall outlet?
current-circuits.hint: Consider current and the total amount of energy involved.

simple-harmonic-motion.text: What makes a motion 'simple harmonic' effectively?
simple-harmonic-motion.hint: Think about the restoring force and its relationship to displacement.

simple-harmonic-motion.text: Why doesn't the period of a pendulum depend on its mass?
simple-harmonic-motion.hint: Consider how mass affects both the restoring force (gravity) and inertia.

simple-harmonic-motion.text: What is the relationship between position, velocity, and acceleration in SHM?
simple-harmonic-motion.hint: Think about the phase differences. When is velocity max? When is acceleration max?

wave-model.text: Do waves transport matter? What actually moves across the ocean?
wave-model.hint: Observe a floating object as a wave passes by.

wave-model.text: What determines the speed of a wave? Frequency, wavelength, or the medium?
wave-model.hint: Think about why sound travels faster in water than in air.

wave-model.text: What is the difference between transverse and longitudinal waves?
wave-model.hint: Consider the direction of particle oscillation relative to wave propagation.

wave-phenomenon.text: Why does a straw look bent in a glass of water?
wave-phenomenon.hint: Think about refraction and the speed of light in different media.

wave-phenomenon.text: How can sound be heard around a corner, but light cannot be seen around a corner?
wave-phenomenon.hint: Consider diffraction and its relationship to wavelength.

wave-phenomenon.text: Why do soap bubbles have colorful swirls?

standing-waves-resonance.text: How do standing waves differ from traveling waves? What is actually 'moving' in a standing wave?
standing-waves-resonance.hint: Think about energy transport versus energy storage.

standing-waves-resonance.text: What conditions are necessary for resonance to occur? Why is it sometimes dangerous for bridges or buildings?
standing-waves-resonance.hint: Consider the relationship between the driving frequency and the object's natural frequency.

standing-waves-resonance.text: In a standing wave on a string, why are there points (nodes) that never move, even though the string is vibrating?
standing-waves-resonance.hint: Think about the interference of two waves traveling in opposite directions.

doppler-effect.text: Why does a siren sound higher pitched when approaching and lower when receding?
doppler-effect.hint: Think about how the wavefronts are compressed or stretched by the motion.

doppler-effect.text: Does the driver of the firetruck hear the Doppler shift of their own siren?
doppler-effect.hint: Consider the relative velocity between the source and the observer.

doppler-effect.text: How is the Doppler effect used in astronomy?
doppler-effect.hint: Think about 'redshift' and 'blueshift' of light from stars.

gravitational-fields.text: If gravity is a force of attraction, why doesn't the Moon crash into the Earth?
gravitational-fields.hint: Think about the moon's tangential velocity and projectile motion.

gravitational-fields.text: What does it mean to be 'weightless' in orbit? Is there no gravity?
gravitational-fields.hint: Consider the difference between weight and the sensation of weight (normal force).

gravitational-fields.text: Why do we treat satellites as 'falling' around the Earth?
gravitational-fields.hint: Think about the curvature of the Earth and the path of the satellite.

electric-magnetic-fields.text: What IS an electric field? Is it real or just a mathematical tool?
electric-magnetic-fields.hint: Think about the space around a charge. How does another charge 'know' to experience a force?

electric-magnetic-fields.text: Why do we use the concept of 'field' at all? Why not just talk about forces between charges?
electric-magnetic-fields.hint: Consider situations with many charges, or when we don't know all the charges present.

electric-magnetic-fields.text: What does it mean that electric field points 'away from' positive charges and 'toward' negative charges?
electric-magnetic-fields.hint: Think about what would happen to a positive test charge placed in the field.

motion-em-fields.text: Why does a charged particle move in a circle in a magnetic field?
motion-em-fields.hint: Consider the direction of the magnetic force relative to the velocity.

motion-em-fields.text: How does a cyclotron accelerate particles if the magnetic field does no work?
motion-em-fields.hint: Think about what actually increases the speed versus what changes the direction.

motion-em-fields.text: Why don't neutral particles experience a magnetic force?

induction.text: How can a changing magnetic field create an electric current? Where does the energy come from?
induction.hint: Think about the work done to move the magnet or change the field.

induction.text: Why does the current induced always oppose the change that produced it (Lenz's Law)?
induction.hint: Consider conservation of energy. What would happen if it aided the change?

induction.text: How does a transformer work? Can it work with DC current?
induction.hint: Think about the need for a *changing* magnetic flux.

structure-atom.text: Why didn't electrons just spiral into the nucleus in the classical model?
structure-atom.hint: Think about the problem of accelerating charges radiating energy.

structure-atom.text: What evidence proved the existence of a small, dense nucleus?
structure-atom.hint: Review the Rutherford gold foil experiment results.

structure-atom.text: Why are atomic spectra (colors of light emitted) discrete lines instead of a continuous rainbow?
structure-atom.hint: Think about electron energy levels and quantum jumps.

quantum-physics.text: Is light a wave or a particle? What experiments support each view?
quantum-physics.hint: Compare the photoelectric effect with the double-slit experiment.

quantum-physics.text: What does the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle really mean? Is it just a measurement problem?
quantum-physics.hint: Consider the fundamental nature of wave-particles, not just clumsy instruments.
Think of it as a 'packet' or quantum of electromagnetic energy.

radioactive-decay.text: Why does radioactive decay happen randomly? Can we predict when a specific atom will decay?
radioactive-decay.hint: Think about the probabilistic nature of quantum mechanics.

radioactive-decay.text: What is a 'half-life'? Does it mean the substance is gone after two half-lives?
radioactive-decay.hint: Consider the mathematical nature of exponential decay.

radioactive-decay.text: Why are some isotopes stable while others are radioactive?
radioactive-decay.hint: Think about the balance of forces (strong nuclear vs electric) in the nucleus.

fission.text: Where does the energy in nuclear fission come from?
fission.hint: Think about binding energy per nucleon and mass defect (E=mc^2).

fission.text: What is a chain reaction? Why is 'critical mass' needed?
fission.hint: Consider neutrons produced vs. neutrons lost.

fission.text: Why is nuclear waste dangerous for so long?
fission.hint: Think about the half-lives of the fission products.

fusion-stars.text: Why is fusion so hard to achieve on Earth compared to fission?
fusion-stars.hint: Think about the conditions needed to force positive nuclei together.

fusion-stars.text: How does the Sun keep burning for billions of years without running out of fuel?
fusion-stars.hint: Consider the vast mass of the Sun and the efficiency of fusion.

fusion-stars.text: Why are heavier elements like gold only formed in supernovae?
fusion-stars.hint: Think about the energy required to fuse elements heavier than iron.
